title: Promote Natural Liver Health: Lifestyle And Diet
author: Karolyn Gazella
description: Maintaining normal body weight and eating a healthy diet is critical to maintaining and protecting liver health.
cleaned_text: Liver health cannot be emphasized enough. The liver plays a role in nearly every organ system in the body as it interacts with and influences [detoxification](https://fullscript.com/blog/natural-detoxification), digestion, immunity, and metabolism, and it performs hundreds of functions throughout the day. ( [6](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK535438/)) As a result, if the liver is not functioning optimally, it can negatively influence health on many levels. Keeping the liver healthy and strong is of paramount importance and requires a focus on both diet and dietary supplements. But before we dig into proactive prevention and protection of the liver, let's take a closer look at liver health concerns and who is most at risk. Liver health concerns Given the numerous tasks the liver has to perform constantly, it is a very active organ helping to digest food, remove toxins, and store energy. Unfortunately, many different types of health conditions can impact the liver's ability to do its job including: - Fatty liver disease or cirrhosis caused by drugs, poisons, or too much alcohol - Inherited conditions such as Wilson disease - Liver cancer - Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease - Viruses such as hepatitis ( [11](https://medlineplus.gov/liverdiseases.html)) Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease By far, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is the most common cause of liver dysfunction. NAFLD affects 25% of the world's population, with that incidence expected to increase by up to 56% over the next ten years. ( [5](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41575-020-00381-6)) Whereas high alcohol intake is the primary cause of cirrhosis of the liver, [obesity](https://fullscript.com/blog/obesity), type 2 diabetes, and metabolic syndrome are the primary causes of NAFLD. ( [10](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6334080/)) Risk factors for NAFLD Several factors can increase the risk of NAFLD and other chronic liver diseases including: [Diabetes](https://fullscript.com/blog/prevent-type-2-diabetes-naturally)and blood sugar control issues - Excess [alcohol consumption](https://fullscript.com/blog/alcohol-use-disorder)and alcoholism - Hepatitis B and C - High fat and/or high sugar diet - Obesity - Prolonged drug use ( [9](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6860746/)) Maintaining normal body weight and eating a healthy diet is critical to maintaining and protecting liver health. Best diet for liver health The best diet for liver health may be the [Mediterranean diet](https://fullscript.com/blog/mediterranean-diet), which is not surprising considering the broad range of health benefits that come from following this eating pattern. Several studies have shown that the greater the adherence to the Mediterranean diet, the lower the risk of developing both fatty liver disease and NAFLD. ( [7](https://bmcmedicine.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12916-019-1251-7))( [15](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4064079/)) A 2021 systematic review found that the Mediterranean diet can both successfully prevent and address NAFLD. In that review, the authors attributed the diet's positive liver health benefits to the antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects of the fruits, legumes, vegetables, and olive oil that are prominently featured in the diet. ( [4](https://www.cureus.com/articles/59985-the-significance-of-the-mediterranean-diet-in-the-management-of-non-alcoholic-fatty-liver-disease-a-systematic-review)) As mentioned previously, foods to avoid for liver health include alcohol, simple sugars, and unhealthy fats like trans and saturated fats found in fried foods and certain baked goods. ( [9](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6860746/)) In addition, dietary supplements can also help support liver health. Best supplements for liver health For many patients, supplementing the diet with certain nutrients and medicinal herbs may also be beneficial to enhance and protect liver health. Some of the key nutrients and herbs for liver health include curcumin, dandelion, milk thistle, glutathione, vitamin D, and vitamin E. 1. Curcumin [Curcumin](https://fullscript.com/blog/curcumin-health-benefits), an antioxidant and anti-inflammatory plant chemical found in the turmeric (Curcuma longa) plant, has been shown to support liver health. A 2019 randomized controlled trial found that curcumin reduced the severity of NAFLD in patients with the condition. ( [12](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31168845/)) This is consistent with results from a 2016 randomized placebo-controlled clinical trial that showed improvement in NAFLD after just eight weeks Dandelion Dandelion (Taraxacum officinale) is another herb that has been shown to positively influence liver health. It has antioxidant activity and the prebiotic fibers in dandelion helps reduce fat accumulation, oxidative stress, and inflammation in the liver. ( thistle extract [Milk thistle is a free radical scavenger that modulates enzymes associated with the development of cellular liver damage, cirrhosis, and fibrosis. ( [3](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7140758/)) While some studies have shown no benefit, most of the studies do show that milk thistle can effectively support liver health. ( [2](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/1217238)) 4. Glutathione Glutathione, often called the "master antioxidant," supports the liver by enhancing detoxification pathways. In addition, as an antioxidant that is found in high concentrations in the liver, it can also help reduce the risk of and address several liver diseases including NAFLD, alcoholic liver, hepatitis B and C, and liver cancer. ( [16](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7997318/)) 5. Vitamin D [Vitamin D](https://fullscript.com/ingredient/vitamin-d) has been shown to reduce the risk of liver inflammation, fibrosis, and cancer. Deficiency of this nutrient has also been linked to many illnesses including liver disease. ( [1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925443917300030#bb0115)) 6. Vitamin E Vitamin E is also an antioxidant nutrient that can support health on many levels including liver function. According to a 2015 meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials, vitamin E significantly improved liver function and was deemed an effective treatment for NAFLD. ( [14](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0899900714005188?via%3Dihub)) The bottom line The liver intimately interacts with nearly every system in the human body, and keeping this organ healthy benefits overall health and quality of life. A healthy diet and a number of dietary supplements, including nutrients and medicinal herbs, can help support liver function. If you are interested in protecting and enhancing your liver health, consider working with an integrative practitioner before making any changes to your wellness plan.
